article:
A 'lithotroph' is an organism that uses an inorganic substrate (usually of
mineral origin) to obtain reducing equivalents for use in biosynthesis (e.g.,
carbon dioxide fixation) or energy conservation via aerobic or anaerobic respir-
ation. http://faculty.weber.edu/mzwolinski/IntroMicro/1113Units/Unit%203/Li-
totrophs%20and%20Phototrophs.pdf Known chemolithotrophs are exclusively
microbes; no known macrofauna possesses the ability to utilize inorganic
compounds as energy sources. Macrofauna and lithotrophs can form symbiotic
relationships, in which case the lithotrophs are called "prokaryotic symbionts".
An example of this is chemolithotrophic bacteria in deep sea worms or plastids,
which are organelles within plant cells that may have evolved from
photolithotrophic cyanobacteria-like organisms. Lithotrophs belong to either the
domain Bacteria or the domain Archaea. The term "lithotroph" was created from
the Greek terms 'lithos' (rock) and 'troph' (consumer), meaning "eaters of
rock". Many lithoautotrophs are extremophiles, but this is not universally so.

Different from a lithotroph is an organotroph, an organism which gets its
reducing agents from the catabolism of organic compounds.
